author: disneydt

title: 10t XL Pulley for SAE Prusa Mendel

description.text: The Prusa git repository does not convert T5 belt (5mm) to XL belt (0.20") when generating STL for the SAE version. The pitches are so close that the pulley appears to work, but the ratio of tooth to space is different so there is backlash when the pulley reverses as the small teeth slide in the large gap. This is a variation of a 10t XL gear that Rick at MakerGear sells with his kit. His STL didn't print well for me due to slight printing inaccuracy causing the grooves in the pulley to fill up with material. This one is derived from an SCAD source here on Thingiverse. The grooves for the belt teeth are 25% deeper than nominal. Rick's STL is on github: https://github.com/MakerGear/MakerGear-Prusa-Mendel

Print two (one for Y, one for X). Drill out the hub to 5mm. Insert a M3 nut in the base (yes, M3 even though SAE Prusa builds for #6 -- #6 is far too huge for a setscrew). Recalculate your X/Y_STEPS_PER_MM as 200 steps/rotation 8 microsteps/step / (0.2 inches/tooth 10 tooth/rotation 25.4 mm/inch) = 31.496 steps/mm. Note that you must adjust this for XL belt even if you elect to use the original 8t pulleys because the distance moved is 0.2"8, not 5mm*8.

comments.text: Awesome! This fixed a bunch of issues I was having with my machine! I had no idea it was the belts!

Absolutely love your ball-joint design but felt the octo head was just a bit too simplistic.  Plus my unit's mascot is the Devilfish, so I remodeled it in zbrush to better fit our logo.

title: Sound square - calibration and noise check object

description.text: This is yet another test part, a right triangle with legs on X, Y, and one at 45 degrees.  Designed to use very little filament, or not be printed at all.  Can be used to check relative noise levels of X and Y axes, or squareness of alignment.

Scale the part to fit your print bed when slicing.  You may choose to run the printer with no filament, just to check the noise of the axes (a dB meter may be useful).  Otherwise, print with minimal infill, then check with a carpenter's square to see how well-aligned your printer's axes are.

This is an adapter to attach a Hampton Bay solar post-cap light to the top of a 4x6 post. The lights only come with standard 4x4 and 6x6 post size adapters, but of course I don't have standard-sized posts.

The adapter was designed in three separate parts to allow for printing without the need for supports; there is a base, an insert, and the tabs. Print the base and insert flat-side down, and the tab part goes on its side. I printed the tab part at the same time as the base by putting in the middle cut-out area. Once all three pieces are printed, the tabs go into the insert, and the insert goes into the base. Note: you will most likely have to sand down the top ridge on the insert to get it all the way into the base as I made my tolerances super-tight. Habit. Sorry. Once assembled, the tabs will go into the bottom of the light in the same way the kit adapters do: put the tabs in the larger part and twist counter-clockwise to lock into place. If you have problems getting the tabs into the light without the light pushing the tabs back through the insert, you could use some glue to keep them fully extended. I didn't have to, but I could see that being an issue. I did NOT design in any screw holes as the attachment to the post can be done in different ways. I heated a small nail and pushed it through the plastic where I wanted holes. Note 2: As is with most building materials, a 4x6 post is not actually 4x6, but rather 3.825x5.5 or some variant of that. Be aware of that if you go to change the object -- measure your posts!! :-) If you're wondering about the concentric pattern on the outer layers, I sliced the parts using Simplify3D which has that option for solid-layer infill.

This is a mount for a Dropcam for the TAZ 5. It clips onto the front bracket of the Y Axis and has adjustable camera angle. This gives me a better view of the print then the typical top down view. STLs are attached and the parametric model is hosted on OnShape where you can get a free account. https://cad.onshape.com/documents/2d9c471e578b4fdc8b66f18c/w/4f9d918ed7ca41e99775d3be/e/65c4442b42054040a908ae7a

Print 2 Right Side Plates, 1 Mount, and 1 Bottom Support.  
I print everything flat except the Bottom Support, which I print oriented with the top edge on the plate.  This way you don't need support.  
Then you link the Side plates into the Bottom Support, press fit is tight but solid.  Next insert the Mount into the holes and slots.  Feel free to use a 3mm bolt and washer to secure the angle of the camera.  The fit is snug enough that I don't think it is necessary, but the holes are there if you need them.

I'm always shuffling though my parts pin to find the right power supply so I bought a mini buck converter unit to create a variable voltage power supply.
I connected this device to a 31.5 VDC laptop power supply and now I can adjust the output voltage to whatever I need. Specs:
Input Voltage: DC 5~40V
Output Voltage: 1.25V~37V (continuously adjustable, the input voltage must be 1V higher than the output voltage)
Output Current: 2A(normal and stable), 3A Max. <$10, DROK Brand Voltage Switching Regulator at Amazon:
http://bitly.com/1NoRCQx
(Make sure to choose the option that has the LED display & heatsink!)

Printed successfully at 20% infill with 2 perimeters.   
You may want to hot glue the voltage regulator to the bottom part to keep it permanently fixated.

title: Comic Book Frame for 8" printer (123D source included)

description.text: A printable comic book frame for American comics, which apparently come in a standard size. It has a 3mm lip around the edge to hold in a piece of glass without blocking the art and holes on the inside walls for toothpicks or paperclips as retainers. See instructions for more.

This is a big one - I had to turn it on a 45-degree angle to fit a 200mm build platform. I included the 123D Design file if anyone wants to try and break it into smaller chunks.
  • Print 2. I went with 25% infill and each half of the frame weighs over 100g. You could go with less, but then the surfaces where the parts mate might not turn out well. Let me know how it goes.
  • Assemble with your glue of choice. I used JB Weld and put clamps on it to hold the joints and keep the frame square.
  • Get a piece of glass at the hardware store. Chat up the person cutting your glass. Show them the frame, and tell them that it's supposed to be 6 5/8" by 10 1/4", but this guide on the internet said that the 6 5/8" was just a hair too much to sit nicely.
  • With the frame face down, lay in the glass, your comic book of choice, and a layer of corrugated fiberboard. You call it corrugated cardboard, but it has a much better and cooler name than that and you just learned it. Stick paperclips or toothpicks into the tabs to hold everything down. Nobody's going to look back there, anyway.

author: KillerFrost

title: Advanced Delta Printer Calibration (tower position + individual diagonal rod)

description.text:
This calibration object will help you to calibrate angle and size errors on your delta 3d printer These errors are typically caused by tower position errors and different diagonal rod lengths. This calibration object will show if your printer suffers from sizing and angle errors and the instructions will help to solve these errors. My Achatz easyDelta printer had a 1 degree error in angles and over 1mm error in sizing in certain directions. This is caused by the towers not being positioned at a perfect 120 degree angle around the center, and small individual size errors between the rods. First errors must be fixed on the printer itself, but on some printers this might not be possible. I used a jig to glue the joints to the diagonal rods, but small errors (1/10 mm) result in bigger errors in the print. The basic delta printer calibration steps are:
  • calibrate the print bed on each tower position by adjusting the z-height for each carriage
  • correct for bowl/dome shape by adjusting the DELTA_RADIUS parameter
  • tune the print size by adjusting the DIAGONAL_ROD parameter
    • After the basic calibration you might experience that the actual print is not equal sized in all directions and the angles in all directions are not as they should be. Resulting in for instance trapezoid objects instead of square-angle objects. The next calibration step is to detect these errors and calibrate your printer. These errors are typically caused by tower misplacement and differences in diagonal rod length. After calibrating the tower angles and individual diagonal rod lengths using the marlin firmware, I managed to achieve 0 degree angle error and a maximum of 0.1 mm size error in any direction in the print ! The calibration object is printed after the basic calibration. Print out the calibration sheet and use this sheet to measure the angles between the X-Y-Z towers. Use a slide caliper to measure the print size in the X-Y-Z tower direction and calibrate your printer in the Marlin firmware. Check the instructions for the calibration steps and how to correct this.

Printer:

Achatz easydelta remodeled

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm with 0.4mm nozzle

Notes: use PLA or PLA/PHA

Print the calibration object in PLA with 0.2mm layer height and 30% infill using a slow print speed (max 30mm/s). Do not use ABS as ABS shrinks (0.7%) when cooling. The 3 towers on a common delta printer are 120 degrees apart at a certain distance from the center (0,0) . The calibration object will show tower misplacement errors and differences between the diagonal rods to the x, y, z carriage. Prerequisites
  • Make sure your towers are square and rigid to the print bed. Use a square to ensure that the printbed is absolutely square to the towers
  • Using an 3 point adjustable printbed will help to set the printbed square and adjust whenever necessary after the initial calibration
  • Have adjustable endstops on each carriage and a accurate endstop switch (optical or switch without lever) mounted firmly to your frame/rod
    • carriage with adjustable z-height: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:738217 rigid end stop holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:642363 rigid easyDelta 3d printer towers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746202 Instructions:
  • make sure your towers are square to the print bed and rigid
  • having adjustable endstops on each tower makes calibration easier
  • calibrate your printer to the print bed by using the adjustable endstops and the DELTA_RADIUS parameter (marlin?: configuration.h) to correct for bowl/dome shape, see note below
  • print the calibration object (normal or small version)
  • measure the angles between the x,y,z tower markers using the calibration sheet (120 degree). The sum of the angles must be 360 degrees
  • measure the print sizes in each tower direction using a sliding caliper (60mm)
  • correct the angles and sizes in the marlin software, see below
  • return to step 3 to check the calibration and recalibrate if required
    • The changes for the tower angles and individual rod length are done in the marlin_main.cpp (Marlin v1.0.2, see below for Marlin v1.1.0-RC2) Angle correction look for the definitions for COS_60 and SIN_60 and add definitions for 58, 59, 61 and 62 degree # define SIN_58 0.8480480961564259 # define COS_58 0.5299192642332049 # define SIN_59 0.8571673007021122 # define COS_59 0.5150380749100542 # define SIN_60 0.8660254037844386 # define COS_60 0.5 # define SIN_61 0.8746197071393958 # define COS_61 0.4848096202463370 # define SIN_62 0.8829475928589269 # define COS_62 0.4694715627858907 On my printer the angle between x-y was 120, y-z was 121 and z-x was 119 degree. Use the Z tower as a base and correct the tower position for the X and Y tower (see pictures for explanation):
  • X-Z angle is 119: therefore change the tower 1 (x) angle in the firmware to 59 degree
  • Y-Z angle is 121: therefore change the tower 2 (y) angle in the firmware to 61 degree
    • The towers angles is used in 2 different places in the marlin_main.cpp and you best can change at both places delta_tower1_x= -SIN_59*delta_radius; delta_tower1_y= -COS_59*delta_radius; delta_tower2_x= SIN_61*delta_radius; delta_tower2_y= -COS_61*delta_radius; delta_tower3_x= 0.0; delta_tower3_y= delta_radius; Size correction Measure the x,y,z leg on the printed object and note down the measurements. Use the measured size most near to the required size to correct the general print size using the DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD value in the configuration.h. See the note below on how to correct this Now recalculate the print size for the other measurements by subtracting the general error from the measured sizes and use these values to correct the diagonal rod for each individual rod. Look for the next line in marlin_main.cpp (also defined in two different places in the marlin_main.cpp: float delta_diagonal_rod_2 = sq(delta_diagonal_rod); and add a squared diagonal rod definition for each rod including the size correction float delta_diagonal_rod_2_x= sq(delta_diagonal_rod*(60.25/60)); float delta_diagonal_rod_2_y= sq(delta_diagonal_rod*(60.31/60)); float delta_diagonal_rod_2_z= sq(delta_diagonal_rod); Look for the function: calculate_delta in the marlin_main.cpp file and replace the calculation with the code below: delta[X_AXIS] = sqrt((delta_diagonal_rod_2_x) - sq(delta_tower1_x-cartesian[X_AXIS]) - sq(delta_tower1_y-cartesian[Y_AXIS]) ) + cartesian[Z_AXIS]; delta[Y_AXIS] = sqrt((delta_diagonal_rod_2_y) - sq(delta_tower2_x-cartesian[X_AXIS]) - sq(delta_tower2_y-cartesian[Y_AXIS]) ) + cartesian[Z_AXIS]; delta[Z_AXIS] = sqrt((delta_diagonal_rod_2_z) - sq(delta_tower3_x-cartesian[X_AXIS]) - sq(delta_tower3_y-cartesian[Y_AXIS]) ) + cartesian[Z_AXIS];' I will use my measurements as an example:
  • x size: 60.67mm
  • y size: 60.73mm
  • z size: 60.42mm
    • The z size is most accurate and therefore I used this measurement to correct the general DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD (configuration.h) 308.7 * (60.42/60) = 310.86 (this formula is not the correct way, but gives a good starting point) Then I recalculated the print size (z size should have 0 error now)
  • x size: 60.67 - 0.42 = 60.25 mm
  • y size: 60.73 - 0.42 = 60.31 mm
  • z size: 60.42 - 0.42 = 60.00 mm
    • And I used the recalculated print size to correct each individual rod length float delta_diagonal_rod_2_x= sq(delta_diagonal_rod*(60.25/60)); float delta_diagonal_rod_2_y= sq(delta_diagonal_rod*(60.31/60)); float delta_diagonal_rod_2_z= sq(delta_diagonal_rod); note:
    DELTA_RADIUS increase for dome shape and decrease for bowl shape. The center (0,0) height will remain the same and the height at the outer positions will increase/decrease DIAGONAL_ROD increase if actual print size too big and decrease if too small. Use the following formula to correct the diagonal_rod value: new_diagonal_rod = diagonal_rod * (measured_print_size/required_print_size) Marlin v1.0.2
    The above instructions are all based on the Marlin firmware. I used v1.0.2 when I made this instruction. I recently tested with Marlin v1.1.0-RC3 which features the individual diagonal rod parameters, but lacks the tower angle correction. Also I get issues many new issues and therefore decided to stick to version 1.0.2.

comments.text:
The more you came near the correct size, the worst the formula works.
Don't ask me why... I'm not a mathematician.
But be aware the fact that changing a tower value, it will reflect over other towers, because of the delta math design.
As an example, I've corrected x-2, y-1.8, z-1.4 to correct an x deviation of .56, and changed the radius by 3mm to compensate build plate convexity.

For calibrating the individual rod length, it not only depends on the length of one rod, but al three influence eachother.

comments.text:
If I correctly understand from the Marlin code, in recent version (1.1.0-RC2) you can just define in Configuration.h:
#define DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD_TRIM_TOWER_1 (DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD*60.3/60 - DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD)
#define DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD_TRIM_TOWER_2 (DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD*60.05/60 - DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD)
#define DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD_TRIM_TOWER_3 (DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD*60/60 - DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD) // Means zero :)
comments.author: Tha_Reaper

comments.text: Hello :)
comments.author: GrAndAG

comments.text:
Yes. These defines do not exist in configuration.h file by default. But they are used in the code. They are defined elsewhere as "0" if there is no definition in configuration.h file.
So, just define them in configuration.h file and these values be used.

comments.author: repetier

comments.text:
Simple solution is to add the 3 lines for eeprom output to your firmware. See eeprom.cpp in you should find the first 3 lines with the next 3 lines missing:
writeFloat(EPR_DELTA_RADIUS_CORR_A, Com::tDeltaRadiusCorrectionA);
writeFloat(EPR_DELTA_RADIUS_CORR_B, Com::tDeltaRadiusCorrectionB);
writeFloat(EPR_DELTA_RADIUS_CORR_C, Com::tDeltaRadiusCorrectionC);
writeFloat(EPR_DELTA_DIAGONAL_CORRECTION_A, Com::tDeltaDiagonalCorrectionA);
writeFloat(EPR_DELTA_DIAGONAL_CORRECTION_B, Com::tDeltaDiagonalCorrectionB);
writeFloat(EPR_DELTA_DIAGONAL_CORRECTION_C, Com::tDeltaDiagonalCorrectionC);

description.text: The Sprinkler Head distributes water evenly over plant leaves to enhance plant health and growth. Can be installed above each bottle (underneath drip nozzle). Fits 3/8 inch tubing. Visit our website (https://www.3dponics.com) and join our Google+ community (https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/111638904033818784260) to take 3Dponics to the next level! Want to know how much it would cost to print this part? Visit https://www.3Dprintler.com and compare prices from today's top 3D-printing services.

3D Printing Settings:
-Low quality; 0.2 mm; 2 shells; 10% infill Tested on MakerBot, Ultimaker, M3D Micro and Formlabs

Panel is made from 9pcs 6x6 inch mono cels (4.5W per cell).
From top its covered by 4mm glass, bottom is 3mm aluminium sheet. The gap between cells and aluminum sheet is filled with termopasta (for cooling), sealed with silicone. All mounting elements is printed - see attached files.
The panel is installed 4 weeks ago and still alive. It gives 0.6amps during raining days and up to 6 amps in sunny days. Hope then latter in summer it will produce up to 9 amps as promised by cells manufacturer.

comments.text: Lots of nice work here.  I'd be concerned about "weather-vaning" or even breakage on windy days.  A strong lateral wind could create a lot of torque at the pole mount.  I'd be tempted to find a way to secure the corners to the ground or even try to find a way to allow it to turn as the wind blows it but returning to home location when the gust is over.  It is often very windy where I live, so that is a big concern for me, but it may be less so for you.  Good luck with this.  I particularly am impressed with the fact that you built your own panels.  What a great experiment.  Hope it goes well. :-)
comments.author: foxpup

This is a cover for this power supply, and many very similar ones http://www.ebay.com/itm/150946378624?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1439.l2649 It is a modification of the RepRapPro cover to fit this particular power supply. Aside from the different cover size, the DC and mains sides are reversed, and a different mounting system is used because of a different screw hole configuration. Additionally, the DC cable hole is larger so that thicker cables can fit.

The cover is held in place by four screws which compress the metal plates.To fit the cover, put it in place then screw the 4 screws, through the external walls and into the holes in the arms inside, so that all off them hold the metal plate tightly. You will probably have to clear the external holes so that the screws go through without resistance, and screw with enough force into the internal holes while the cover is off, so the holes clear out.

title: Replacement switch lever for Metcal MX500

description.text:
This is a replacement for the part that slides up and down and controls the iron select switch on Metcal MX500 soldering stations.  
It's a quick hack-up so the openscad code is ugly and measurements are a little rough, but works fine for me after a little cleanup with a file & sandpaper for smooth operation (as you can see from print in gallery, filament feed also wasn't calibrated for this print).

I printed w/ABS, then filed / sanded a little for smooth operation.  
I used white-out to color the areas that show through the windows to indicate which connected iron is currently selected.

author: Oswaldo44

title: Easy - High Voltage Driver Circuit - Flyback

description.text:
This is an easy to make project for a High voltage power source.
"HIGH VOLTAGE GUNS, MORE DEAD PEOPLE AND MORE HIGH VOLTAGE FUN" Make sure to check out the instructions. Be careful while handling high voltages, this has enough energy to stop someones heart. WARNING: I AM NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY INJURIES OF ANY KIND. PLEASE DO NOT HANDLE HIGH VOLTAGES WITHOUT KNOWLEDGE. IF YOU HANDLE HIGH VOLTAGE WITH NO EXPERIENCE, DEATH MAY OCCUR. IF YOU EXPERIENCE DEATH, PLEASE CONTACT YOU DOCTOR IMMEDIATELY.

• Find an old CRT television (An old television mainly used during 1990s or later, these are the televisions that were large and are pretty common to find.), these contain a component called a Flyback Transformer, google to make sure what a CRT television is and what a Flyback looks like.
  • Find all the pin outs (Go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wNmZ1xxh1G8 It really helped me out when I first started)
  • Wrap wire around the core, its the bar hanging off the flyback. The wire should be going down anti-clockwise and around 10 turns.
    4.Use the schematic to wire it up, the notches on the board should tell you where each wire goes to. The schematic should still help.
    5.Go to Radioshack and buy a 9 volt battery pack, wire this to the board and you should get high voltage.
    • If you have any problems let me know in the comments, I worked hard to make sure it worked before I published. FAQ
    1.Q: My flyback gave me arcs but then it stopped working!
    A: Try putting in a new 2n3055 Transistor, and put a heatsink if you feel the transistor getting hot.
    2.Q: My arcs are tiny! Nothing like in the picture
    A: This happened to me too, the solution is to switch the leads going to the flyback primary.
    3.Q: Im really confused
    A:If you dont understand how I explained it go to: http://www.instructables.com/id/reupdated-Simple-flyback-driver/?ALLSTEPS
    4.Q: I dont have time to find the primary coil
    A: If you dont want to find the primary coil you can wrap your own around the core on the flyback, this will decrease your arcs though.
    5.Q: How many volts should I put in?
    A: I recommend a 6 AA Battery Pack.

author: mb20music

description.text: This is a pair of adjustable pliers based on a rotating tongue-and-grove mechanism. They are fully functional, and are especially useful in cases when non-marring tools are required. The form of these pliers, especially in terms of the handle shape and ergonomics, is derived from a very old pair of pliers manufactured by the Diamond Tool and Horseshoe company. However, the adjustment mechanism is of a more modern style, and is identical in principle to modern commercial products available from many manufacturers. This model may be scaled as needed depending on your needs, and functions well at any size. Since Galaktican reports that the snap ring is a bit tight, it may be advisable to scale this component up by 2-3% relative to the other parts. Also, thanks to the folks at 3dPrint.com for writing a nice article about this thing! http://3dprint.com/55290/3d-printed-pliers-tools/
All three parts should be printed in the given orientations with no support material. A high infill density is necessary if the pliers are to be used for heavier gripping tasks.

comments.text:
If you don't mind a bit of self-promotion here, I did a video about these pliers over at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LGVGSwVGbUc

comments.text: I also had problems with the snap ring being to tight when printed in PLA. My solution was to remove it from the printbed as soon as it was done, keeping the part hot and deformable. Then it is quite easy to position correctly and squeeze onto the locking rod.

comments.author: Thomasheisler

comments.text:
How strong would you say these are?
Would there be any need to beef up the ends of the jaws to prevent them from snapping under higher load?
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: I'd say that these are quite strong, depending on the material and settings that you use. Ideally, a high strength material such as Taulman nylon or ABS/PC alloy should produce a pair of pliers that are stronger than the user. I don't think that beefing up the distal ends of the jaws is necessary; I ran a test yesterday and found that the pivot pin will fail in shear before the jaw surfaces yield. You should definitely make sure that this pin, as well as the tongue boss, is printed 100% solid. Cheers!
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: What do you suggest for slicer settings? infill/solid layers etc.
comments.author: zeedeeh

comments.text: For the two main pieces I recommend 3 perimeters, 90% infill density. No support is required. If you are using Slic3r you can knock the infill density down to 25-50% and set the solid infill threshold area at 90 mm^2; this will print the handles hollow, but keeps the main pin and tongue/grooves solid. I would print the snap ring totally solid. Cheers!

author: SL7rips

description.text: Lance Spaghetti is a little gadget, who can strafe spaghetti!

Usable serrated knife with a 3.38" blade and 4.0" handle. Great for opening thick plastic bags and sawing through cardboard.  
Originally created as a dedicated knife to be kept by the stove for opening wood pellet bags.  
This is a remix of my previous Serrated Knife. I have improved upon the size, shape, and feel of the handle. The "blade" has a slimmer profile.

The design is broken into 3 main components: the left and right halves of the knife, and the dowel.  
Print the left and right halves on their flat sides so as to give the knife as much strength as possible. You will need to print 2 dowels, which are to be glued into either one of the knife halves. With the dowels in place, glue the two halves together. It would be advisable to use some clamps or place weight on the assembly while the glue sets to minimize the gap between the two halves.

author: Zonyc

title: Ball Lock Two Speed Robot Transmission

description.text:
This is a 3D printed proof of concept and display model for the USFIRST robotics team "The Tigertons 222" Ball Lock transmission printed by me. The original three speed version we used in 2004 was inspired by the 1970's five speed Hodaka motorcycle transmission Since 2004 we have been changing up the design a bit. This year/season we located the shifting relief springs to the outside of the transmission rather than inside the shifting shaft. The transmission works by forcing four steel balls into the gears by a plunger inside the shifting shaft. To shift gears the plunger slides out from under one gear to underneath the next gear. This retracts the balls down into the shifting shaft which allows that gear to spin freely on the shaft. Once the plunger goes to the next gear it forces the balls underneath that gear to lock into that gear. Please see the following for more information: Here is a video I made of this prototype transmission:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rj6naPPiQOw Here is a video I made many years ago:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D7ng4OWilUY Here is an animation I made many years ago:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jZc3npI1Mdk Feel free to check out:
www.tigertrons.net
www.usfirst.org The pictures show the 3D printed transmission in white ABS. The completed CNC machined transmission with some actual end use 3D printed parts. The original 2004 transmission. As you can see we have improved the design greatly! The five speed Hodaka shifting shaft and gears. The complete Tigertrons robot.
I have not included all the transmission files due to several reasons.  This posting is mainly for educational purposes.  If you seek to build your own feel free to inspire your design off of ours.

comments.text: Nice design though it's no rocket science. The stl files are not printable. After converting them to gcode using slic3r 0.9.10, it appears that output shaft has only 0.7 mm high, so in turn it's more like you have not included the transmission files at all, probably due to several reasons ;)

remixed_from.author: skovgaar
remixed_from.title: Earbud Holder Redux - 20% longer and more!

title: Earbud Holder Redux - [Rotated for better printing]

description.text:
Been running into problems with this model (not in the model itself) but rather the orientation the STL's force it to be printed in.  You see, once it's printed, to get the two covers to clip onto the body, you have to flex them.  Because of the orientation that it's printed in, you're flexing it right along a print line.  When you do that, in every attempt I had made, the tab snaps off.  
Printing it along the horizontal plane allows you to flex it perpendicular to the printed plane, which prevents it from snapping off.  Simply changing the orientation corrected this problem.  
The print doesn't come out quite as slick, but a bit of sanding of the edges where it sat on the print bed makes it perfect.  
I've included the main body in the files as well for convenience sake.

this vase was created by a happy accident while playing around in openscad. and as happy as i am now i'd like to share it with you... UPDATE 5th October 2017
Version 3 is uploaded. This version should be in the right scale (200mm Height) the design of this vase is based upon a custom made guitar pick/plectron (PLActron - the customizable & biodegradeable guitpick), which is rotated 240 degrees around the z-axis an extruded along a sine in z. casually inspired by:
  • Thing 16378 - yet another vase
  • Thing 745938 - PLActron (yet unpublished)
  • Alle Achtung - Schwerkraft

this model is scaled to be printed with 20cm height,
which should fit most printers and most flowers. you can download not one, but 3 different versions of this vase.
while the smallest with 32 segments adds some interesting geometry, the 500seg is the way to go if you want a smooth shape, if you can't decide take the 100seg-version slicing suggestions for Cura 15.02.1

• Standard config
    Print Speed: 42mm/s yes, this is essential
    Layer Height: 0.1 mm
    Shell Thickness: 0.8mm
    Retraction off
    Bottom/Top Thickness 1.1mm
    Fill Density: 0%
    No Support, No Platform adhesion

  • Expert config;
    Section Infill: uncheck "Solid infill top"
    Section Black Magic: check "Spiralize the outer contour"
    • printing time with these settings on an Ultimaker 2 is under 6 hours this model is quite easy to print, no overhangs and no detailed structures, you could print it in 0.3mm > Layers without much hesitation. If you have problems getting this vase watertight, try raising the values for Shell Thickness and/or Bottom Thickness. You could also try to set the Shell Thickness to a non-multiple of you Nozzle Size, so the Outer Walls overlap.

This is doorstop that I designed in Sketchup as my first fully homemade 3D print... thought I'd upload it since I had it sitting around.  It's 40 x 40 x 120mm so not huge, but probably bigger than it needs to be unless you had a really big gap under your door!  The bottom surface is designed to grab onto carpet without damaging the pile and the top is stepped to grip the bottom of the door nicely.
Download it and print it.  A higher fill density might be required so you dont crush it with the door.

title: Collared bearing pin for iamjonlawrence's no-sag Simple Y-axis mod

description.text:
Collared bearing pin for iamjonlawrence's no-sag Simple Y-axis mod.  
My belt was threatening to slip off when retracting, so I tweaked Jon's bearing pin to add a collar that keeps the belt aligned.  
Printed relativley fast on my (modified) Simple. 100% infill for max strength.

Printing was not anything special.  
Installation however was a challenge.  
Be careful that you don't displace the nut holding the original bearing pin in place. Replacing that nut without completely disassembling the Y-axis mod is not fun.  
I knocked the nut out. grrr. However, some 14guage copper wire, some crazy glue to hold the nut to the cleverly bent wire and I was able to re-insert the nut and reassemble the unit as noted in the picture.

title: i3 Adjustable Y Belt Holder for GT2 & T2.5

description.text: i3 Adjustable Y Belt Holder for GT2 & T2.5 I decided to combine the designs of the Prusa i3 Adjustable Y-belt Tensioner & Holder and i3 Rework X-Carriage for GT2 & T2.5 together into a new Adjustable Y Belt Holder. You can attaching T2.5 or GT2 belts much easier and without using zip ties and of course, adjustable. Ah don't mind the funky colors, I'm testing the new E3D Cyclops and had some Navy Blue (60%) mixing with a white (40%) to get a little blue. As you can see, not all filaments mix well. :) BOM: 1 M3x30mm bolt & nut and 2 M3x15mm or 2 M3x10mm to attach to build plate.

First of all great thanks to the project F-F-Fiddle (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:219040) for idea of the violin printing.
But after some time I decided to draw my own electric violin which will be more look like classic violin and also will use some classic violin parts.
Violin was printed on Prusa i3 printer from PLA plastic. All violin parts are constructed with sizes suitable for printer bed 200 x 200 mm. Sizes of violin are close to classic violin 4/4. Strings, bridge, shoulder rest, chinrest are classic violin parts. Sound pickup with preamp were bought on ebay (you can find it by search words "electric violin pickup"). Pegs of violine were borrowed from guitar parts.
Here is shot video about it http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3aOdIlK4IfM

Assembly of violin
http://youtu.be/vwLUZtvNNxM materials list:
Printed parts - 5pcs
bridge - 1pcs
sound pickup - 1pcs
electronic preamp - 1pcs
guitar pegs - 4pcs
metal rod M8x370 - 1pcs
screws:
m4x25 - 9pcs
m4x50 - 1pcs
m4x40 - 2pcs
m3x8 - 4pcs (for pegs)
m2x10 - 4pcs (for electronic preamp) nuts:
m4 - 12pcs
m3 long nut - 4pcs for hot installation in holes (for pegs screws) m2x10 - screws for electronic preamp I melt it directly in plastic Plastic parts I print from PLA with Prusa I3 printer. I'm using slicer Slic3r with fill density 10% but probably with 20-30% sound will be better.

title: Titanium Conveyor For Makerbot ABP and raftless printing

description.text:
This is a replacement for the plastic conveyor that comes with the makerbot thingimatic ABP. Simply it replaces the plastic conveyor with a strip of Titanium foil. Titanium foil may be difficult for the average person to find, but it is available for purchase online and the results are worth the initial investment. Other high strength metal foils like zirconium or tungsten would probably work similarly. It seems to last nearly forever too, I've run several hundred prints on the same small strip of metal without any noticeable wear. Titanuim foil is an ideal platform material because:
1) Unlike aluminum foil it does not normally crinkle and maintains a smooth flat shiny surface unless deliberately creased. It it actually somewhat springy.
2) It is flexible like a sheet of paper and rolls smoothly through the mechanism
3) The coefficient of thermal expansion is much lower than plastic over the temperature ranges used, therefore although the plastic will adhere nicely when hot, when both are cooled the plastic shrinks more than the surface beneath it and pops right off.
4) It is physically extremely tough and will survive a lot of abuse
5) It is chemically inert and immune to solvents The titanium build surface is immune to solvents, and this allows a unique sort of raft-less printing. Essentially what you do is use waste plastic dissolved in acetone to rapidly paint on a thin film that helps the first print layer stick. This has the key benefit of conserving useful material and saving the time needed to print a raft. I've had a great deal of success with this using ABS plastic, never tried it with any other plastic. So far using this technique my prints have shiny smooth bottom surfaces and no warping or pre-mature detachment or slumping type defects. I've never had to abort a print due to a failed first layer and it's pretty much my main method now. If you want to print normally with a raft, the film is not needed and the raft adheres very well to the metal. EDIT: It seems like other people have used the scrap plastic-acetone method before on metal build platforms, didn't realize that when I came up with it. As far as I know this is still the only metal build surface that rotates and functions like the original conveyor belt though.

nstallation
1) Measure the conveyor you removed, add several centimeters for attachment purposes, and cut this length of foil from the roll or larger piece.
2) If your piece is too wide measure the appropriate width and trim it down to size. I was lucky that my piece was pretty much the right width, but the continuous piece needs to be at least as wide as the platform you want to use, trimming down is easy but attaching multiple strips side to side won't work well.
3) Remove the rear conveyor spindle and thread the foil through the mechanism. Overlap the foil slightly and use scotch or capton tape on the inside of the loop to eliminate an edge and again on the outer surface for strength.
4) Insert the spindle again and tension the belt. The tape adheres quite well to the titanium surface and the belt is fairly strong. It may take some troubleshooting to get the right belt size and tension, if you remove the tape do so slowly and carefully, sudden forceful movements can put tiny little crinkles in even this foil.
5) That's it! Happy printing. You will need to use the control panel to rotate the belt between prints to ensure that you're printing on a clean metal surface and not over the tape. Printing Raftlessly:
1) Take scraps of ABS (eg. rafts from other prints, failed or broken prints, small scraps of filament, etc. Everyone probably has plenty of this lying around) and put them in a jar with a layer of acetone. The acetone fully dissolves the ABS into a pasty sort of goop. There's no exact mixture but in the end it should have a smooth creamy consistency somewhat like molasses. play around a bit, if you make it too thick or thin it is easy to evaporate off some acetone or add more. It may take several hours to overnight to fully dissolve uniformly depending on the size of your starting scraps.
2) Use a brush to apply a light coating of the ABS solution to the Ti Build surface, try to get it as uniform as possible and only cover the area where a raft would normally go. It is best to do this when the platform is cold, if the platform is hot the ABS solution may bubble into a foam and negatively affect print quality.
3) Print normally on this coated surface, disable the raft in the skeinforge settings before making your g-code.
4) When the print is done, trim away the excess film from the edges of the bottom. It should be transparently thin and papery, the layer actually below the print remains with it and adds negligibly to the height, the only noticeable or measurable difference is a smooth shine finish. Note the second image is a view of the bottom of a large flat surface I printed using this method, notice the nice smooth flat finish.

comments.text: UPon more reflection regarding using a highly non-thermally conductive material as a heating medium. Heat will dissipate through a path of least resistance. Yes, your belt will warm up - reluctantly, because Titanium is VERY non-thermodynamically conductive. It will get warm/hot but, the heat generated by your heating circuit will stay mostly in the board and will migrate more through the platform. This in the long term probably would not matter for a home toy that will not be used for long and is well designed (MB is well designed for the board - that is my opinion). On a long build you can expect the entire platform to begin to be very warm. Yes, the platform is temperature controlled and fortunately or unfortunately shut off when at temp. but, then your belt won't be at the temperature you want/need it to be. So, what will happen? The operator will complain and crank on the heat. This then raises the heat generated and well the oven you have created beneath the Titanium belt gets nice and toasty.
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: Remember that the original conveyor belt supplied with the kit was made of kapton plastic, which is listed by DuPont as having a thermal conductivity coefficient of 0.37 W/mk. The thermal conductivity coefficient for titanium is 21.9W/mK, so the Titanium conveyor is at least 59 times as conductive as the original, possibly more as the foil's high strength allows it to be thinner than the plastic. I've printed hundreds of prints on this with the platform set to the recommended 120 deg, and there is no problem with heating. See the calculations below that I made in response to bstott, the build surface of titanium 0.025mm thick has a thermal conductivity of 8760W/K, which is about 17.5x more than the total max output of the makerbot's 500W power supply.

comments.text: You are also forgetting tho other advantage of titanium.  Very low thermal expansion.  In theory this would allow you to run the belt while the platform is hot and not stretch the belt.  In practice this means less time between prints when printing using the abp.
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: Yes, the titanium will be totally unaffected by the heat and will rotate just fine when hot. If you're going to do this though be sure that the tape you use in attachment is thermally resistant. Kapton should be just fine. As I listed in the original description another consequence of the low thermal expansion is that when the platform is allowed to cool the differential shrinkage between the plastic and metal causes them to pop apart, but they can adhere fairly well while hot. If you try to eject a part while hot, be prepared for the possibility that it will stick to the metal and warp. It could probably be done with some skill, but I'd try it on a small part first.
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: The heating isn't a problem at all. While titanium is a poor thermal conductor as far as metals go, even this metal has a MUCH higher thermal conductivity than plastic or paper that is typically used. The thermal conductivity of titanium (in SI units) is 21.9W/mK vs 0.17M/K for ABS plastic. Also consider that the actual rate of heat transfer is dependent on material thickness and the foil is extremely thin. Thermal conductivity p=k*A/L where k=thermal conductivity coefficient, A=area, L=thickness. We have k=21.9 W/mK for Titanium. The foil thickness is 0.025mm=2.5E-5m. The platform has an area of 10cmx10cm=0.01m^2. Plugging these numbers into the above formula we find a total thermal conduction rate of 8760W/K for the platform, which is absurdly more than sufficient.

gt;

comments.author: nophead

comments.text: You can get titanium shim stock for what I suppose are reasonable prices.  For example, mcmaster-carr 5747T11 is .005" (.125mm, so thicker than what's proposed here) in a 6" x 50" roll for US$76.20 plus shipping.  Personally, I doubt mcmaster is the cheapest source, but even so that's several belts' worth.
comments.author: nophead

comments.text: For that matter, you could try steel or stainless steel shim stock of about .001" (.025mm) for considerably less, although you might find it didn't care for being bent repeatedly in a tight curve.
comments.author: pandelume

comments.text: titianium is absolutely perfect for this because it does not have a memory like most other alloys and wants to go back to the original unbent state.
comments.author: pandelume

comments.text: Ntitnol is cool stuff and a roll made of it would be a truly eternal conveyor belt, the heated build cycles could naturally restore any damage. There are suppliers of nitinol foil but it seems way more expensive than even Ti. Heating Ti can occasionally remove crinkles, but be careful because the foil starts to oxidize and become gradually brittle at high temp. The only real opportunity for crinkling is during installation. Once it's in it stays smooth because the backing and tension prevent it from getting enough strain in any dimension to be permanent.
comments.author: zgbot

comments.text: I'm not sure exactly what the thickness is because it didn't say on the roll, but my calipers give a reading between 0.02 and 0.03mm, so I'd guess around 0.025mm since that's a pretty standard foil thickness. A pretty wide range should work though, it just needs to be flexible enough to roll and tough enough to last. Honestly I'd probably prefer thicker if I could find it, the thinner you go the more easily it crinkles, anything below 0.1mm would probably still roll just fine.
comments.author: nophead

Two modular towers build of small sections - one top is "rapunzel" like, the other one is a castle type.  
Enjoy ! My daugthers love it !  
PS: The castle tower has two colors here...just because the first print failed halfway through, and I printed the second part in a different color before gluing them together ;)

All parts can be printed with no support. Might need a bit of sanding to have a perfect match, but it works quite well on my prusa I3 with no post-processing. Here some settings I used:

  • cylinder 1, 2 and 4: 0.3mm layer height, plain

  • rapuntzel top: 0.2mm layer height, plain. Using a fan would give better results, but mine was broken. Also, preferably print with 30 or 40 infill...mine is a bit too heavy

  • castle top: 0.3mm layer height, plain - again an infill of 30 or 40 would be better

  • base: printing plain is here better - gives more stability is not used on a duplo plate

description.text:
Update: due to popular request I've rotated the hexagons so that when the sheets are fitted in a hive the bottom of the cell will be a flat instead of a "V"
This of course is the roller with "90deg" at the end of the name.
My brother and his friend get spare wax from their beehives but have to pay for the wax foundation with the hexagon pattern. This is an experimental roller set. The commercial ones use a much wider diameter drum pair. My first print of a roller took 24 hours! I have a Rostock delta that can go to around 300mm high so this was one long vertical print. We found that wax was too sticky on the PLA I used. I'd recommend using nylon for the print but then you have to work with nylon's high shrinkage. Ideally a laser powder printer would do a better job for this print. If anyone has success with this, please let me know and I'll amend the instructions. There was also some minor flex that affected the drawing accuracy of the top end cog, a thick brim could have improved that.

Do a couple of short partial prints first to check your material's ability to release from wax. There are on line tutorials for making flat wax sheet. PLA didn't work for me.  
Use M16 hardened steel threaded rod for the shafts. Leave enough on an end for a handle and fitting of needle bearings because the designed in bearings are too high a friction.

comments.text: How well do your bees like your pattern? I ask because all the foundation I've seen uses the "Qbert pattern" of repeating cubes instead of flat hexagons. I'd designed one almost identical to what you have here but then I saw the repeating cubes pattern on all my foundation and wondered which would be better. I had far more success in designing the hexagons than the cubes though because figuring out how to wrap that pattern around a cylinder so that it repeats properly is mind-bogglingly hard.
comments.author: ehrichweiss

comments.text: Also, I didn't check the dimensions of your design but most foundation rollers are for rolling along the length of the wax. That is to say that you feed them the narrow end of the wax sheet, not the wide end. If your design is supposed to be used that way then you need to adjust your comb 90 degrees because the bottom of the honeycomb cell is supposed to be flat.
comments.author: ehrichweiss

comments.text:
Length of hex cells on roller is a match for width of cells on a bought foundation sheet.
No idea what you mean by " need to adjust your comb 90 degrees because the bottom of the honeycomb cell is supposed to be flat."
And you think the outside of the male hex stubs on my rollers aren't??
comments.author: ehrichweiss

comments.text: You read it wrong is all.  If you watch a video of someone rolling foundation, you'll see what I mean.  The orientation of the cells as you have them on your design would require you to feed the foundation's wide side instead of the narrow side. If I rolled foundation with your design the way that I would normally roll foundation, the bottom of the cell wouldn't be level, it'd be a "V". Does that make sense now?
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text:
I think you are talking 2d.
Bottom of a cell is at other end of the cell from where the bee caps a full cell of honey off. 3d bottom is what my roller prints into both sides of the wax.
When wax sheet is placed in hive, the under(side) of the cells from my roller would form a v like you said. I did this to produce a less wasted area on the longer side but im neither a bee or a bee keeper. If this orientationis 30° different to a BEE's normal packing plan then I don't know, is it a deal breaker for them or would they simply adapt? To me, it was the more sensible orientation but now you have me wondering!
comments.author: ehrichweiss

comments.text: Yeah, you got the gist of what I was saying(hard to describe this stuff without good pics, etc.). They may put honey in the resulting comb but AFAIK they won't put any brood in it. It took me a while to design mine so that it would have that "bottom" wall flat. I spent more time trying to figure out how to measure the cells in the other orientation though because then instead of there being X number of cells along the surface, you have to think in terms of the number of cell PATTERNS for the surface because in the other orientation you have 1 cell and then a part of the cell below it. Just so you know, the length of that pattern is equal to 3 times the length of one side of the hexagon. This is because the "diagonal" height of a cell is 2 times the length of one of the sides, and to finish the pattern you add one more side length. Again, you'll do better to look at the orientation to see what I mean but it'll suddenly make sense. There's a hexagon calculator online that'll help you figure these things out if you haven't already found one, btw.
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text: A followup on the subject. I was looking into whether bees will use "vertical" comb for brood and there seems to be a slight(10% or so) tendency to use vertical cells for drone comb but there's not a lot of info as to whether they actually care overall. Some say they always make it horizontal, some say there's no such thing. So maybe there's nothing to worry about.
comments.author: ehrichweiss

comments.text: I agree if you are going forward your hexagons should be rotated. The bottom of the cell should be flat. If you can rotate the cells easily, I would love it if you would do that.
comments.author: ehrichweiss

comments.text: If you lifted one end of the hive up 30 degrees would the bees have a better quality of life? :-)
comments.author: ehrichweiss

comments.text: No... you can't do that, 30 degrees is way to much. 3 to 5 degrees tilted forward so rain won't run into the hive. Moisture will kill bees in winter. 3rd year beekeeper,  but I like your design.  Wish there were more designs on hive products.  Don't have a printer yet but getting one .
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text: I love the way are pursing this. I'm a beekeeper of over 30 years. I have made many attemps at making rollers with several materials. I don't have a 3d printer. was in process of saving to get one but was injured at work and am now disabled on right side. If you ever make a pair of these I wood be interested in buying a set to build a roller press to see if the bees would except it. what is the cell size? 4.9 or 5.4mm. 4.9mm would be the best size for natural beekeepers to use against verro mites. have you made the pre roller set that levels out the wax  before rolling the design. doing that makes the wax more plyable.  if your are willing to part with a set for me to try please pm me. thankyou

comments.text: I very badly want this to work. I am new to beekeeping but I understand the savings of making your own foundation.
comments.author: JMBishop

comments.text:
This project piqued my interest. I've never kept bees, but an old friend did.
I searched and the machines they use to make honeycomb foundation panels appear very heavy duty... Large aluminum rollers. Big bearings and cast iron frames. I'm not saying the job couldn't be done with plastic rollers. A little ingenuity goes a long way.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: Beekeeper 3 years now, I  would say that most beekeepers use the plastic foundation now because of it's cheap, easy to use, last longer but the main reason is when you extract honey the frames go in an extractor that turns and forces the honey out by way of centrifugal force, if it spins to fast it can blow out the natural bee's wax foundation but needs to spin fast enough to extract honey from  cells with plastic foundation no worries.  Saw this design and would like to try and make and use wax foundation just to try it but the foundation  presses on the market can run $1500 to $2000 way to much just to try it.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: It's not my special interest field either. I think nylon rollers would release the wax much better than PLA. Those big ones you write of, they are used to imprint the pattern into the wax after brushing with a detergent and water mix. I suspect the plastic panels can peel off? Most printers are too small to print a standard sheet. I think the you're right though, even double sided, bridging would be easy across each cell.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: Oh. They only imprint the pattern. That's different. A warm panel seems easy to impress. Nylon would seem better in many ways. It wouldn't chip or crack, and wax release must be superior, particularly if it's soaped.

description.text: I picked up this kit over the weekend as a day project and decided to make an enclosure for it. It's a fun little build, and the directions are pretty straightforward; if you have any electrical talent you might be better off sourcing your own parts (this one even uses the same type of op-amp), but I'm allergic to wiring schematics so I ponied up for a full kit. I don't have the proper bits to make large enough holes in an Altoids tin, so instead of going to the hardware store 2 blocks down the road I spent a couple hours designing this enclosure. I wanted to give the little speaker the best chance it's got, as its slightly underpowered, so it snaps quite snugly into place on the top and there are even standoffs to reduce vibration dampening from whatever surface you rest it on! this is v1, I'll upload a few more parts tomorrow once I piece them all out

print both halves at high infill for strength and so your walls are rooted well; I originally printed at 20% and I can hear the walls creak when I plug my headphones in. If you wish, you can also print the cone, and superglue / ABS weld it on. I'll recommend a knob to print as soon as I find one that fits...

Entrance of  kicc, modelled for exhibition plan.

Testé et validé. voici la version 3 de la chatière (oui la version 2 était trop complexe
et peu fiable), elle évite de faire un gros trou dans la porte, vous aurez seulement 4 petit trous de vis (j'ai repris les mêmes entraxes que
la v1) . Je l'utilise pour laisser passer les chats dans la chambre et
pas les chiens.
Attention lors de la pose, pensez à laisser au moins 15mm entre le bloc fixé sur la porte et le bord de la porte!!!! sinon vous ne pourrez
plus fermer la porte (à cause du chambranle).
pour ouvrir et fermer, il suffit de mettre le doigt sous la goupille coté porte, et de la faire remonter, puis si vous souhaitez fermer l porte, vous pouvez replier le bras, et fermer la porte normalement. ps: je vous conseil de fixer l'ensemble un peu au dessus de la
poignée, évidemment l'effort sur l'ensemble sera plus important si
les chiens forces le passage, mais il évitera que dans la nuit ce soit vous qui arrachiez tout par ce que vous aurez oublié le système!!!

pour ceux qui veulent modifier en partant de la V1, la goupille et le
bloc porte fixer sur le chambranle restes inchangé.

Dans l'idée, il faut coller les 2 parties de la goupille, mais ça tiens
aussi en montage serré.
le bloc porte chat V3 est pour une porte poussant gauche, j'ai rajouté
le bloc porte poussant droit .

--Warning--
this is just a prototype

I needed to make sure that bridges are printed right, before trying to print the x-ends of the Prusa Mendel design.
I tried with a hollow cube, but it wasn't a reliable test for many reasons, so I openscadded a more accurate emulation of the x-ends bridges, which only takes around 3 minutes to print with my settings.

• Try to print the STL
  • If it doesn't do a one layer bridge only, tweak the .scad
  • Take your time to try various bridge settings till you get it perfect.
  • Start your first print of the x-ends with confidence ;)

comments.text: What did you change to be able to make these bridge? I have needed to print a couple things that when bridging it was really stringy and needed alot of cleaning.

salut,
voilà, après avoir constaté que mon extrudeur prenait du jeu en Z à
force d'imprimer, j'ai décidé de faire un support bien rigide qui peut supporter 1 ou 2 roulements linéaires dans sa partie basse. temps: en 50 mm/s, 0.3mm par couche, tête de 0.4mm, comptez 2h

je dois l'avouer c'est du travail pour l'installer, il faudra enlever le galet tendeur de courroie, puis démonter le support de barre lisse en haut à droite, puis desserrer l'accouplement,
dévisser à la main la tige fileté pour l'extraire du moteur, tirer vers
l'extérieur le bloc pour libérer le chariot.
une fois cela fait, insérer les roulements linéaires sans forcer! mais il
faut faire levier avec un tournevis plat dans la rainure pour pousser les roulements à leurs place( pour éviter de forcer, mettez un petit
coup de lime ronde dans les logements des roulements avant de
les monter).
monter le support d'extrudeur et l'extrudeur avant de monter le
chariot sur les barres lisse, sinon bon courage pour visser tout ça.
faire les opérations à l'envers pour le remontage. un message fait toujours plaisir, même pour faire une remarque
constructive.

author: arrowmeiwaracing

description.text:
Many thanks to harmane http://www.thingiverse.com/harmane/about for his idea of vacuum trubine tool http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:496290
I try to make it and find it to complex to print.
so I decide to make very simple trubine.
external size match 52mm http://www.ebay.com/itm/300w-12000RPM-Spindle-Motor-Mount-Bracket-12V-48V-Engraver-Cutter-Marker-CNC-/121245097542?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item1c3ac55e46 to make it you need
  • 2pcs high speed ball bearing, 8x16x5 mm size, ABEC-7 qulity is the best. I find it at ebay http://www.ebay.com/itm/8x16x5-mm-Stainless-Metal-Shield-Ball-Bearings-ABEC-7-SMR688-ZZ-A7-AF2-/251868279954
  • 1pcs ER11A 8mm Straight Shank Chuck with key http://www.ebay.com/itm/C8-ER11M-100L-Straight-Shank-Chuck-Wrench-Deep-Processing-for-CNC-Milling-/191238774516?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_15&hash=item2c86b81ef4
  • 1pcs ER11 1/8" spring collet http://www.ebay.com/itm/ER11-Spring-Collet-Holder-Tool-for-CNC-Workholding-milling-Lathe-tool-1-8-/291269051426?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_15&hash=item43d0fd0422
  • 8pcs m3 60mm long bolt and nut http://www.ebay.com/itm/3mm-x-60mm-SLOTTED-CHEESEHEAD-MACHINE-SCREWS-M3-NUTS-AND-WASHERS-NEW-PACK-OF-5-/261041368296?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_3&hash=item3cc7472ce8
  • print 1 turbine housing, 1 vacuum hose, 2 ball bearing holder, 2-4 bearing cover, 1 turbine blade from harmane http://www.thingiverse.com/download:820170
    • maybe you need also good luck, 3mm drill, vacuum
    you can tune scad files to match your vacuum hose diameter
    unfortunately, I didn`t save scad files for bearing holder and cover, only stl available :( at video http://youtu.be/WSDnS4di9K0 you can see result.
    its 0.3mm drill and I think less than 0.1mm runout. at maximum its difficult to stop it by hands first put bearing in holder
    after put it on shaft using clamp (for example this http://www.ebay.com/itm/Heavy-Duty-Quick-Grip-6-12-Trigger-Speed-Clamp-woodwork-carpenter-spreader-/371222873026?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&var=&hash=item566e9b83c2 )
    using LM8UU liner bearing put it in right position up to 8000 rpm

• prepare er11 shaft, 2 ball bearings, printed parts: bearing cover, bearing holder, bearing cover, turbine blade, turbine housing, bearing cover, bearing holder, bearing cover, vacuum hose, 8 m3 bolts, 8 m3 nuts
  • prepare instruments: drill, 3.0mm or #31/#32 numbered drill bit, carpenters clamp, 2 8mm linear bearings (used as instruments), 5.5mm wrench for nuts and screwdriver for the bolts
  • check all parts, remove brims, check holes for bolts, drill it if needed
  • take ball bearing, using clamp put it carefully inside bearing holder, repeat for second ball bearing
  • take shaft, remove nut and collet, be careful with shaft
  • read "mounting" section of "bearing installation guide" (page 13) http://www.skf.com/binary/tcm:12-114679/140-710%20BIMG%2011_2012_tcm_12-114679.pdf
  • place the first bearing cover on the shaft
  • place the first bearing holder (with inserted ball bearing) on the shaft
  • using clamp mount the ball bearing
  • take linear bearings and using it with clamp put the ball bearing to the right position, remove linear bearings
  • place second bearing cover on the shaft
  • place the turbine blade on the shaft
  • insert assembled shaft in to the housing
  • place the third bearing cover on the shaft
  • place the second bearing holder with inserted bearing on the shaft using clamp and linear bearings, remove linear bearings
  • place the forth bearing cover on the shaft
  • insert the bolts into the holes of vacuum hose holder
  • attach the vacuum hose holder to the assembled turbine
  • use google search for the pictures for the string "flange bolt tightening sequence" for example this http://www.wermac.org/images/bolt_sequence.gif
  • tight the bolts and nuts according the sequence
  • assembly chuck with the collet and the nut, insert 1/8" drill bit into the collet, tight carefully. Don`t tight the nut without collet!
  • check for smooth shaft rotation, attach the vacuum, power it.
  • safety first! be careful of moving parts, drills, drill bits, collet nuts, etc. Use glasses! Extremely recommended to read safety guides like this http://www.ihsa.ca/rtf/health_safety_manual/pdfs/tools_and_techniques/Power_Tools_Drills.pdf

title: Objekt cooling duct for i3 rework with J-Head MKV

description.text:
This is a cooling duct for Prusa i3 rework.  
If you print it, dont use support everywhere, this blocked the airflow inside. Support on the bed cause no problem.

To install the Fan_duct you need:
x2 M3x35 (DIN 912; Allen screw)
x4 M3x12 or M3x14 (DIN 912; Allen screw)
x4 M3 nut
x1 40mm Fan

The 3 brackets are mounted between the towers and the top plate to create a rigid frame and a square angle between the plate and towers.  
I printed these on a well tuned prusa i2 to ensure that the bracket is exactly square.  
A m4 nut holder is added to insert m4 nuts into the 20mm extrusions. I had no t-nuts around, but this works just as well.  
Mount the bracket to the tower using the m4 20mm extrusion nut holder and 2 m4 nuts. The brackets is then attached to the tower using 2 m4x16 screws with a ring. A 4.5x30 wood screw can be used to attach the part of the bracket pointing towards the  center to the top plate
It is raining today, so I decided to design this. It is a 12 well plate laboratory consumable...enjoy
